hints_raw: You need to use the quotient rule and one other rule to calculate this derivative.
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
To begin calculating this derivative, apply the quotient rule. So

\(f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x})' *(3x) - e^{3x} *(3x)' }{(3x)^2}\)

The derivative of 3x is simple to calculate, but in order to calculate \((e^{3x})'\) we will need to use the chain rule as follows:

\(\displaystyle (e^{3x})' = e^{3x}*(3x)' = e^{3x}*3\)

Plugging this back into the quotient rule, we get:

\(f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x}*3)*(3x) - e^{3x} *(3) }{(3x)^2}\)

You can leave this answer as is.
sols_latex:
To begin calculating this derivative, apply the quotient rule. So

$f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x})' *(3x) - e^{3x} *(3x)' }{(3x)^2}$

The derivative of \emph{3x} is simple to calculate, but in order to
calculate $(e^{3x})'$ we will need to use the chain rule as follows:

$\displaystyle (e^{3x})'  = e^{3x}*(3x)' = e^{3x}*3$

Plugging this back into the quotient rule, we get:

$f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x}*3)*(3x) - e^{3x} *(3) }{(3x)^2}$

You can leave this answer as is.
sols_raw:
To begin calculating this derivative, apply the quotient rule.  So

<math>f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x})' *(3x) - e^{3x} *(3x)' }{(3x)^2}</math>

The derivative of ''3x'' is simple to calculate, but in order to calculate <math>(e^{3x})'</math> we will need to use the chain rule as follows:

<math>\displaystyle (e^{3x})'  = e^{3x}*(3x)' = e^{3x}*3</math>

Plugging this back into the quotient rule, we get:

<math>f'(x) = \frac{(e^{3x}*3)*(3x) - e^{3x} *(3) }{(3x)^2}</math>

You can leave this answer as is.
statement_html:
Calculate the following derivative. You may leave your answer unsimplified.

\(\displaystyle f'(x)\), where \(f(x)=\dfrac{e^{3x}}{3x}\).

Calculate the following derivative. You may leave your answer
unsimplified.

$\displaystyle f'(x)$, where $f(x)=\dfrac{e^{3x}}{3x}$.
statement_raw:
Calculate the following derivative. You may leave your answer unsimplified.

<math>\displaystyle f'(x)</math>, where <math>f(x)=\dfrac{e^{3x}}{3x}</math>.
